Sentence: Both transport and magnetic measurements showed that PdTe is a bulk superconductor below 4.5 K. Isothermal magnetization (MH) and magneto-transport (R(T) H) measurements provided the values of the lower (H c1 ) and upper (H c2 ) critical fields as 250 Oe and 1200 Oe respectively at 2 K, establishing that the compound is clearly a type-II superconductor.
Interestingly, Karki et al found a T c of 4.5 K for single crystalline PdTe samples , which is nearly twice that reported in 1953 by Mathias .

Both the H c1 and H c2 at 2 K are marked in the C p (H) plot (inset II, figure ), and are in agreement with the magnetization and transport measure- ments on PdTe superconductor shown in figures 2 and 4.
Resistance versus temperature plot for PdTe from 300 K to 2 K, showing a clear superconducting transition at 4.5 K. Low temperature resistance is fitted to R = R 0 + AT 2 (solid red line).

Worth mentioning is the fact that the electronic specific heat capacity analysis in the present case is done at T = 2 K, which is however lower than the T c = 4.5 K of the studied PdTe superconductor; the same in principle is warranted at a tem- perature of 0.1T c .
Worth mentioning is the fact that this is the first study to our knowledge on the super- conductivity of polycrystalline PdTe with T c of above 4.5 K.
The only other study [12] with T c of above 4.5 K for PdTe is on tiny (15 Î¼m) crystallites.
